text:
Actress and model Ruby Rose isn't afraid to clap back at harmful headlines. She's called people out for speculating on her weight on a number of occasions, and a recent Snapchat story was no different.

After her red carpet appearance for Pitch Perfect 3's Australia premiere, it seems that some people decided to focus on Ruby's appearance rather than her performance. In an Instagram story, she called out reporters who opined on her acne and weight — and everyone who gossips about other people's appearances, in general.

"This acne belongs to me, not them," she wrote on a photo of her cheek. "I don't see how it's bothering so many others? But I'm a human. It happens." And for the record, she's right: there's nothing wrong with acne — it's the most common skin condition there is. Judging someone for their skin is never appropriate.

She then recounted The Daily Mail calling her "anorexic," explaining how this use of the word undermines the experience of eating disorder survivors and spreads the myth that eating disorders are about looks. "They don't care that they are using a term like anorexia as if it isn't a serious and deadly illness," she wrote. "It is very important to know what an eating disorder is, to know how to speak about it properly when you have such a platform such as a national newspaper. To consider the readers, triggers, and straight up bullying."

The actress added that she has a tilted posterior and "spinal curvature from a bad car accident," which might lend to the appearance that sparked the gossip and speculation. But she shouldn't need to defend the way she looks. Someone's looks and health are entirely their business, and gossiping about them is a form of bullying. To prevent more negativity from starting as a result of her candid discussion, Ruby turned off the comments on her Instagram. "I can only do what I can to make this a safe place," she wrote, "and I will."
title: Ruby Rose Claps Back at Tabloids for Criticizing Her Acne and Weight
